A Simple Neural Hack to end Distraction and get off the internet!
Distraction is hard to resist because it is an affective state, as it is embodied by increases in dopamine levels due to the novel outcomes implicit in distractive events. Dopamine adds transitory utility or value to moment to moment decisions and is harmful to effective decision making when it is not aligned with long term goals, as we well know by succumbing daily to social media, emails, and other distractors. The best way to eliminate distraction is to pursue meaningful activities that have more significant affective outcomes, or to induce greater positive affect by managing the unique ways incentive motivation works in the human brain. To demonstrate this latter point here is an easy procedure to increase meaningful behavior, accentuate positive affect, and eliminate distraction.
Simply follow a simple resting protocol (mindfulness procedure is best for this), and simultaneously pursue or anticipate pursuing meaningful behavior (e.g. cleaning house, writing poetry, exercise, etc.). Do this continuously for standard sessions of a least a half hour and chart your progress. As a result, you will be more pleasurably alert, engaged, and incented to continue being productive and resist distraction. Neurologically, this is due to ‘opioid-dopamine’ interactions, or the fact that rest is pleasurable due to the induction of opioid activity in the brain. Meaningful activity on the other hand induces dopaminergic activity, which is felt as a state of alert arousal but NOT pleasure. Opioid and dopamine neurons are located adjacently in the midbrain, and when both are simultaneously activated will also co-stimulate each other, resulting in enhanced feelings of arousal and pleasure. Indeed, when rest is accompanied by highly meaningful behaviors (creating art, athletic achievement), pleasure and alertness are highly accentuated, resulting in ‘peak’ or ‘flow’ experiences. So, there is my procedure to increase productivity and reduce distraction, and all without inspirational screeds, lectures, books, or seminars, with the added benefit that you can prove or falsify my hypothesis for yourself, give or take an hour!

This interpretation is based on the work of the distinguished neuroscientist Kent Berridge of the University of Michigan, a preeminent researcher on dopamine and motivation, who was kind to vet the work for accuracy and endorse the finished manuscript.
Berridge’s Site
https://sites.lsa.umich.edu/berridge-lab/

I offer a more detailed theoretical explanation in pp. 47-52, and pp 82-86 of my open source book on the neuroscience of resting states, ‘The Book of Rest’, linked below.
https://www.scribd.com/doc/284056765/The-Book-of-Rest-The-Odd-Psychology-of-Doing-Nothing

Very true. I have no social media whatsoever. Texting is enough. Social media is a MASSIVE industry, so it follows that these companies are going to be using the most devious, underhanded, and brutal ways to keep you scrolling. They prey on your insecurities, tie your self-esteem to something irrelevant and useless, and incentivize obsessive, unhealthy time wasting on what ultimately becomes a parasite. Before long you feel the need to check Facebook, to post on Snapchat, to blah blah blah, because when you don't, you feel invalidated. The hollow husk of social media has become the focal point of your self-worth, the only thing keeping your frail opinion of yourself afloat, and when you stop for even a minute, you lose the ability to focus on anything else, anything that matters. All that matters now is that constant click, click, click, because when you stop clicking, you feel like people will forget you. You can no longer bear the notion of people talking without you present. You have to be there, to be everywhere at once, reminding people that you exist, that your life is amazing too, that your life isn't hollow.                                                                                                                                                     All this festers in your mind - your still growing mind, most likely - and takes a hold on you, a grip, a hook. All of this happens every day, and yet to the world, you are just another teen, mindlessly scrolling in the corner. Don't live an empty life for the approval of others. Live for yourself. Make sure that when you are on your deathbed, when you are looking back on your life, you did yourself proud. Forget all the other zombies. Let them hoard their likes like fool's gold. Give away yours - it's worthless and fake anyway. It won't buy anything. Become the best version of yourself you can be, and remember, the only approval you actually need comes from within.

Social media can be a great tool for communication because it is so prolific in our lives nowadays. If we choose to make it a positive addition that supplements our fast pace lives, rather than distract and overwhelm us, then it can be valuable tool for personal lives as well as for businesses and networking. Social media connects us! Sometimes these connections can seem superficial but as explained in the video studies and statistics show that relationships tend to last when they start on the internet. We tend to put our best foot forward when we present ourselves on social media and leave out any negativity in fear of it not being “likeable”. This always positive presentation of ourselves makes it so we can’t share our actual feelings organically and at the same time put ourselves down because we see so many positive posts that we feel we’re not “keeping up”. Personally, I like that Facebook and other social media platforms “force” us to post positive things. I think it makes us strive to be better and achieve what we want. When we see somebody close to us accomplish something, we are not only happy for them but we feel we can accomplish our dreams as well!

I think a lot of what we associate as “internet addiction” is when people use the internet to escape their reality. The “instant gratification” is, I think, the biggest part. It reminds me of that scene in Inception when the Indian people go into the dream world to escape their reality; they live there. That’s similar to our internet lives, where we are immersed and find ourselves spending hours on them.

A very simplified version and mildly misleading, but not too bad.  Our brains are not being "rewired", this is precisely how we were always wired; we've simply formed a new method to harness it.  Everyone forms compulsive habits and always have, some are more productive than others.  Social media interaction has provided the world a generalized view of events and incite into the minds of every day people from around the world.  I'd also note that while alcohol is physically addictive, most people are only compulsive drinkers and a true physical dependency is difficult to start and quick to end.  Anyone who is "addicted to alcohol" and has been clean for a year... they are not actually "addicted" to alcohol anymore.  Compulsions and addictions are different things, though both are serious.

I started a petition for a way to improve Facebook in this regard by creating a standalone Facebook events app combined with the Facebook Messenger and Group Apps. I requested that the stand alone events app include the Birthday notifications that way you would still be able message your friends Happy Birthday without needing to post it on their wall. By having these three separate Facebook apps combined, you won't need to maintain a Facebook profile or have the news feed and timeliness feature. This way we no longer have to feel the roller coaster ride of emotions from the constant influx of information we receive on our news feeds. We no longer have to feel like we are missing out yet still have the opportunity to feel truly connected. This way you won't have the need to compare your life to your peers and you still would feel a sense of connectedness to them.

If you still like the sharing of photos aspect with your peers and seeing what is going on in their lives then there is always Instagram to do so. That site however can also serve negatively if imitation is used incorrectly. Anyways let's tackle this problem together and move each other closer to freedom without caring and needing approval from those around us for the things we do and don't want to do.

I read this short article on a 8 hour study of teens 13 to 18 years of age going the full 8 hours w/o any electronic interaction (no phone, internet, tv, etc...). There were 68 teens who participated in this study and only 2 went the entire 8 hours w/ no negative feelings or thoughts. The two surviving teens were boys that preferred to go out and play some kind of sport. One boy took the bus over and over again from one end of the city to the other for the eight hours.
The other kids experienced severe panic attacks, intense anxiety, aggravated boredom, etc... One girl went into something of an anxiety induced seizure because she couldn't check her phone for media notifications. Essentially, she showed the same symptoms of a heroine addict going through withdrawal.

It's a good thing that I don't participate in social media.
... Oh wait.

Of course, I enjoy spending time on fora that encourage good conversation and debate (on a topic that isn't your everyday life or when you last took a dump) over the crap that is Facebook, Twitter, G+, etc. In fact, I don't even use those things (for their intended purposes at least): I don't use Facebook, it's obvious why I have G+ (thanks Google, I always wanted a video streaming site that was forcefully connected to a privacy leak...), and I literally only have a Twitter account so that I can participate in a certain reading contest (ReadMOD / Tadoku).

Do I spend too much time online? Yes (but I do the same with books). Do I talk about myself too much? Yes (but I have the brains not to tell everyone in the world my personal information). Am I addicted to social media? No, thankfully; I just don't like the concept. Has it affected my brain? Probably, but considering my abilities, it hasn't done anything particularly negative.
